[[Toronto FC|TOR]] @ [[New England Revolution|NE]] | average attendance = 17,872{{cite web|url=http://www.sbnation.com/soccer/2011/10/24/2511576/mls-attendance-up-2011-major-league-soccer |title=MLS Attendance Was Up Almost Across The Board In 2011 | author=Jeremiah Oshan |date=2011-10-24 |accessdate=2011-10-25}} | prevseason = [[2010 Major League Soccer season|2010]] | nextseason = [[2012 Major League Soccer season|2012]] }} The '''2011 Major League Soccer season''' was the 99th season of FIFA-sanctioned soccer, the 33rd with a national first-division league, in the United States and Canada, and the 16th season of [[Major League Soccer]]. The season marked the arrival of two new league clubs, [[Portland Timbers]] and [[Vancouver Whitecaps FC]], whose cities previously had clubs of similar name play in the [[USSF D2 Pro League]]. Those two new West Coast clubs led to a realignment of the league's conferences, with [[Houston Dynamo]] moving to the Eastern Conference to create two conferences of nine teams each. Each team played a balanced 34-match regular season schedule, playing every team twice (once at home and once away). The regular season began on March 15, when the [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] defeated the [[Seattle Sounders FC]] 1â0 at [[Qwest Field]], and concluded with the host [[Houston Dynamo]] defeating the [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] 3-1 on October 23 at [[Robertson Stadium]]. The season also featured the [[MLS All-Star 2011|2011 MLS All-Star Game]] on July 27, when [[Manchester United]] defeated the [[MLS All-Star 2011|MLS All-Stars]] 4-0 at [[Red Bull Arena (New Jersey)|Red Bull Arena]] (hosted by the [[New York Red Bulls]]). The [[2011 MLS Cup Playoffs]] ran from October 26 until November 20, when the [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] claimed their third MLS championship by defeating [[Houston Dynamo]] 1-0 in [[MLS Cup 2011]] at [[Home Depot Center]] in [[Carson, California|Carson, CA]].{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/nov/21/mls-cup-galaxy-dynamo-landon-donovan-david-beckham/|title=Landon Donovanâs strike gives L.A. Galaxy MLS Cup crown|date= 20 November 2011|work=Washington Times|accessdate=22 November 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsportswest.com/11/21/11/Galaxys-Big-Three-finish-season-on-top/landing_galaxy.html?blockID=609286&feedID=8063|title=Galaxy's Big Three finish season on top|date= 20 November 2011|work=Fox Sports|accessdate=22 November 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/sports_blog/2011/11/mls-cup-galaxy-defeats-dynamo-1-0-to-win-championship.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+LAT_Sports_Blog+%28The+Fabulous+Forum%29|title=Galaxy defeats Dynamo, 1-0, to win championship|date= 20 November 2011|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=22 November 2011}} ==Changes from 2010== A number of structural changes were made prior to this season, involving both on- and off-the field aspects of the league. === Structural changes === To accommodate the arrival of the two new franchises, the league expanded the number of regular season matches to 34 total games. The [[MLS Cup Playoffs]] expanded from eight teams to ten.{{cite web|author=Jonah Freedman |url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/playoffs-expand-10-teams-more-changes-ahead |title=Playoffs to expand to 10 teams; more changes ahead | Major League Soccer |publisher=Mlssoccer.com |date=2010-11-21 |accessdate=2011-10-07}} Beginning with this season, the best three teams from each conference receive guaranteed playoff spots; the four teams with the next best point totals will play one-match knockout games to determine the final participant for each conference.{{cite web|title=MLS sets expanded playoffs format|url=http://espn.go.com/sports/soccer/news/_/id/6152100/mls-decides-structure-expanded-playoffs|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=February 23, 2011}} With the new playoff structure, comes a new incentive for the [[MLS Supporters Shield]] winner, who will play the lowest seeded team to qualify for the conference semifinals. Furthermore, the [[MLS Reserve Division]] returned; the rosters accordingly expanded to 30 players. Other minor changes included the shortening of the [[MLS SuperDraft]] from four rounds, down to three,{{cite web |url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/mls-superdraft-trimmed-three-rounds |title=MLS SuperDraft trimmed to three rounds |date=January 5, 2011 |work=MLSSoccer.com |first=Simon |last=Borg |accessdate=January 5, 2011}} and the expansion of the number of guaranteed spots reserved for away supporters from 150 to 500.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} === Roster rule changes === Team rosters were expanded to 30 players in order to accommodate the re-introduction of the [[MLS Reserve Division]]. Of these 30 players, 18-20 count against a club's salary cap of $2,675,000. Clubs may still have a maximum of three [[Designated Player Rule|Designated Players]] per club, each of whom counts $335,000 for salary cap purposes. The transfer windows for acquisition of players under contract in another country run from January 21-April 15 and from July 15-August 14. Other key roster rule changes were the introduction of Off-Budget players who do not count against a club's salary cap; the ability of clubs to forgo fielding a full roster of 30 players for salary reasons; the introduction of roster slots paid below last year's league minimum; the ability of the two Canadian clubs to count U.S. domestic players as domestic players for roster purposes; and the ability of clubs to buy out one guaranteed player contract during the off-season and free up the corresponding budget space.{{cite web|title=2011 MLS Roster Rules|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/2011-mls-roster-rules|publisher=Major League Soccer|accessdate=February 11, 2011}} === Managerial changes === {| class="wikitable" |- !Team !Outgoing coach !Manner of departure !Date of vacancy !Table !Incoming coach !Date of appointment !Table |- |[[Portland Timbers]] |colspan="4"|

Chivas USA|Chivas USA]] |[[MartÃ­n VÃ¡squez]] |Fired |October 27, 2010 |8th West ('10) |[[Robin Fraser]] |January 4, 2011 |Pre-season |- |[[Toronto FC]] |[[Nick Dasovic]] |[[Caretaker manager|Caretaker]] |September 14, 2010 |5th East ('09) |[[Aron Winter]] |January 6, 2011 |Pre-season |- |[[Vancouver Whitecaps FC]] |[[Teitur Thordarson]] |Fired |May 29, 2011 |9th West ('11) |[[Tom Soehn]] |May 29, 2011 |9th West ('11) |- |[[Chicago Fire Soccer Club|Chicago Fire]] |[[Carlos de los Cobos]] |Fired |May 30, 2011 |8th East ('11) |[[Frank Klopas]] |May 30, 2011 |8th East ('11) |} == Teams == Two new expansion clubs entered the league: [[Portland Timbers]] and [[Vancouver Whitecaps FC]]. These clubs, alluding to their history, are the immediate successors to clubs that played in the [[USSF D2 Pro League]] in 2010, and before that the [[USL First Division]]. Both clubs also bear the names of members of the [[North American Soccer League|original North American Soccer League]]. Further, the Kansas City Wizards rebranded as [[Sporting Kansas City]] and moved into their new stadium at [[Livestrong Sporting Park]] in [[Kansas City, Kansas]]. Finally, with the arrival of two West Coast clubs, the [[Houston Dynamo]] transferred to the [[Eastern Conference (MLS)|Eastern Conference]].{{cite web|title=Houston Dynamo switch to Eastern Conference|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/houston-dynamo-switch-eastern-conference|publisher=Major League Soccer|date=January 28, 2011}} === Stadiums and locations === {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Both of the new teams to MLS received jersey sponsors, while several existing teams saw changes in jersey sponsorships for the 2011 season. *[[Alaska Airlines]] signed on as the first MLS shirt sponsor for the [[Portland Timbers]]. *[[Bell Canada]] became the first shirt sponsor for [[Vancouver Whitecaps FC]] in its MLS incarnation. *[[Glidden (paints)|Glidden]] declined to renew its jersey sponsorship of the [[Columbus Crew]],{{cite news|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/foxsoccer/mls/story/Glidden-withdraws-Crew-shirt-sponsor|title=Glidden withdraws Columbus Crew shirt sponsorship|agency=Associated Press|work=[[Fox Soccer Channel|FoxSoccer.com]]|date=2011-01-10|accessdate=2011-07-02}} which has not yet found a replacement. *[[Greenstar]] are the new shirt sponsor for the [[Houston Dynamo]],{{cite web |url=http://www.houstondynamo.com/news/2010/12/dynamo-unveil-greenstar-jersey-sponsor |title=Dynamo unveil Greenstar as jersey sponsor |date=December 7, 2010 |publisher=[[Houston Dynamo]] |accessdate=January 17, 2011}} replacing [[Amigo Energy]]. *[[Bimbo Bakeries USA|Bimbo]] will serve as the first ever shirt sponsor for the [[Philadelphia Union]].{{cite web |url=http://www.philadelphiaunion.com/news/2011/01/union-partner-bimbo-bakeries-official-jersey-sponsor|title=Union Partner with Bimbo Bakeries as Official Jersey Sponsor |date=January 11, 2011 These include: signing players on transfers/free transfers as is done in most of the world; via trades; drafting players through mechanisms such as the [[MLS SuperDraft]], [[MLS Supplemental Draft]], or [[MLS Re-Entry Draft]]; rarely used methods which cover extreme hardship and injury replacement; signing players as [[Designated Player Rule|Designated Players]] or Homegrown Players; placing a discovery claim on players; waivers; and methods peculiar to MLS such as through allocation or a weighted lottery.{{cite web|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/2011-mls-roster-rules |title=2011 MLS Roster Rules | Major League Soccer |publisher=Mlssoccer.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-07}} === Allocation ranking === The allocation ranking is the mechanism used to determine which MLS club has first priority to acquire a U.S. National Team player who signs with MLS after playing abroad, or a former MLS player who returns to the League after having gone to a club abroad for a transfer fee. The allocation rankings may also be used in the event two or more clubs file a request for the same player on the same day. The allocations will be ranked in reverse order of finish for the 2010 season, taking playoff performance into account. Once the club uses its allocation ranking to acquire a player, it drops to the bottom of the list. A ranking can be traded, provided that part of the compensation received in return is another clubâs ranking. At all times, each club is assigned one ranking. In the unlikely event that all clubs use an allocation, the order begins anew with [[Vancouver Whitecaps FC]]. === Weighted lottery === Some players are assigned to MLS teams via a weighted lottery process. A team can only acquire one player per year through a weighted lottery. The players made available through lotteries include: (i) [[Generation adidas]] players signed after the [[MLS SuperDraft]]; and (ii) Draft eligible players to whom an MLS contract was offered but who failed to sign with the League prior to the SuperDraft. The team with the worst record over its last 30 regular season games (dating back to previous season if necessary and taking playoff performance into account) will have the greatest probability of winning the lottery. Teams are not required to participate in a lottery. Players are assigned via the lottery system in order to prevent a player from potentially influencing his destination club with a strategic holdout. |title=Sporting Kansas City win lottery for college phenom Saad | Major League Soccer |publisher=Mlssoccer.com |date=2011-07-05 |accessdate=2011-10-07}} |} ==Related competitions== ===International competitions=== ====CONCACAF Champions League==== {{Main|2010â11 CONCACAF Champions League|2011â12 CONCACAF Champions League}} Prior to the start of the MLS regular season, [[Columbus Crew]] and [[Real Salt Lake]] played against each other in the quarterfinals of 2010â11 edition of the CONCACAF Champions League. The first leg, contested at Crew Stadium on February 22, 2011; ended in a scoreless draw between the sides. On March 1, 2011; the second leg at Rio Tinto Stadium was played, where Real Salt Lake won the series against the Crew 4-1 in the game and on aggregate, this ending Columbus' Champions League campaign. As a result, Salt Lake became the first MLS team to advance into the semifinals of the Champions League under its current format.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} The team won its home fixture against [[C.D. Saprissa|Saprissa]] of Costa Rica 2-0 on March 15, 2011. Real Salt Lake lost the away fixture 2-1 on April 5, 2011, but advanced 3-2 on aggregate. They faced [[C.F. Monterrey|Monterrey]] of Mexico in the first leg of the final on April 20 in Monterrey. The game concluded in a 2-2 draw. The second leg was played at Rio Tinto on April 27, 2011. Monterrey won 1-0 (3-2 on aggregate) with a late goal in the first half. [[Colorado Rapids]] and [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] have qualified directly into Group Stage for the 2011-12 edition of the Champions League by being the [[MLS Cup 2010|MLS Cup]] and [[MLS Supporters Shield|Supporters' Shield]] winners, respectively. Both [[Seattle Sounders FC]] and [[FC Dallas]] have earned preliminary entries in the tournament by winning the [[2010 Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup Final|U.S. Open Cup]] and finishing runner up in the MLS Cup, respectively. [[Toronto FC]] secured the Canadian berth in the preliminary round with their [[Voyageurs Cup]] victory on July 2. ====World Football Challenge==== {{Main|2011 World Football Challenge}} On March 29, 2011 MLS Commissioner [[Don Garber]] confirmed that the 2011 edition of the [[North American SuperLiga]] would be replaced by the [[World Football Challenge]],{{cite web|last=Borg|first=Simon|title=World Football Challenge will replace SuperLiga|url=http://www.dcunited.com/news/2011/03/world-football-challenge-will-replace-superliga|work=MLSSoccer.com|publisher=D.C. United|accessdate=14 July 2011}} a [[Friendly match#Association football|friendly]] tournament which started play on July 14 and will end on August 6.{{cite web|title=Rules of the Competition|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/wfc/rules-of-competition|work=World Football Challenge|publisher=MLSSoccer.com|accessdate=14 July 2011}} The following MLS sides entered the tournament based on invitation: [[Los Angeles Galaxy]], [[Philadelphia Union]], [[New England Revolution]], [[Chicago Fire Soccer Club|Chicago Fire]] and [[Vancouver Whitecaps FC]]. ===Domestic competitions=== ====Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup==== {{Main|2011 Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup|2011 Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup qualification}} The MLS clubs that finished first through sixth place overall during last year's regular season earned a direct bye to the third round proper of the U.S. Open Cup. Clubs that finished seventh or lower will have to play for the final two spots in a series of play-in propers, based on their geographic location as well as their final regular season position. ====Canadian Championship==== {{Main|2011 Canadian Championship}} The two Canadian-based MLS clubs, [[Toronto FC]] and [[Vancouver Whitecaps FC]] participated in the Canadian Championship, Canada's domestic soccer cup. They competed against two other professional Canadian soccer teams from the [[North American Soccer League (2011)|NASL]] for the Voyageurs Cup, as well as a Preliminary Round birth in the CONCACAF Champions League. The tournament is organized in a knockout format with two-legged ties in both the semifinals and final, with the away goals rule in place. The two began in the semifinal round, where the Whitecaps defeated the [[Montreal Impact]] and Toronto defeated [[FC Edmonton]]. The first leg of the final, held in Vancouver on May 18, ended in a 1â1 draw. The second leg, on May 25 in Toronto, was abandoned due to torrential rains with the Whitecaps leading 1â0. Under competition rules, the second leg was to be replayed in its entirety the following day, but the field remained unplayable. The second leg was replayed, again in its entirety, on July 2, with Toronto winning the game 2-1 and the championship 3-2 on aggregate. ===League competitions=== ====MLS Cup==== {{Main|2011 MLS Cup Playoffs}} Following the 2011 season, ten MLS clubs will qualify for the MLS Cup Playoffs postseason tournament. Of the ten clubs, six will be automatic qualifiers from the top three clubs in each conference. These automatic qualifiers earn a bye to the conference semifinal, or quarterfinal round proper. Four more qualifiers will enter in a play-in round, where these for clubs will be determined by their final regular season standing, regardless of their conference. The winners of the play-in games will play in the conference semifinals, where the lowest seeded club will play against the [[Supporters' Shield]] winners. The cup final will be held on a neutral venue. ====Cups and Rivalries==== {{Main|MLS rivalry cups}} This season marks the first time that the [[Cascadia Cup]] will be contested in [[Major League Soccer]]. [[Seattle Sounders (1994â2008)|Seattle]], [[Portland Timbers (2001â2010)|Portland]] and [[Vancouver Whitecaps (1986â2010)|Vancouver]] contested this cup from 2004-08 until [[Seattle Sounders FC|Seattle]] joined [[Major League Soccer]]. The competition continued between Portland and Vancouver for the next two years. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Major League Soccer}} {{2010â11 in North and Central America, and Caribbean Football (CONCACAF)}} {{2011â12 in North and Central America, and Caribbean football (CONCACAF)}} {{2011 in American soccer}} {{2011 in Canadian soccer}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Major League Soccer Season 2011}} [[Category:2011 Major League Soccer season| ]] [[Category:Major League Soccer seasons|2011]] [[Category:2011 domestic association football leagues]] [[Category:2011 in American sports]] [[de:Major League Soccer 2011]] [[es:Major League Soccer 2011]] [[fr:Major League Soccer 2011]] [[it:Major League Soccer 2011]] [[nl:Amerikaans voetbalkampioenschap 2011]] [[pt:Temporada 2011 da MLS]] [[zh:2011å¹´ç¾åè·æ¥­è¶³çå¤§è¯ççå­£]]
